para.paratext:
Documentary evidence is evidence derived from conventional symbols (such as letters) by which ideas are represented on material substances.[
1] A party must authenticate a writing before a court can admit it into evidence. Authentication is the means by which a writing is shown to be what it purports to be[2] and is determined by the court. Some writings require that their execution be established. Georgia's new Code section, O.C.G.A. § 24-9-901, follows Fed. R. Evid. 901 in requiring only that evidence admitted at trial be sufficient to support a finding that the matter in question is what its proponent claims. Thus, a party seeking to authenticate records under Rule 901 is required to present evidence of a prima facie case that the evidence is what it purports to be. Once that is established, the court may then admit the evidence, and the ultimate question of authenticity will be decided by the factfinder.[
3] However, a proponent's burden of authentication of evidence is light; there need be only some competent evidence in the record to support authentication, which can consist of circumstantial evidence.[
4]

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-9-903, like its federal counterpart Fed. R. Evid. 903, the testimony of a subscribing witness is not necessary to authenticate a record unless required by the jurisdiction whose laws govern the validity of the record. Georgia law remains the same in this area except a party offering a handwriting specimen to the opposite party for comparison must do so at least 10 days prior to trial.[
5]
O.C.G.A. § 24-9-901(b)(2) states that a writing may be authenticated by “nonexpert opinion based upon familiarity not acquired for purposes of the litigation.”
In Williams v. State ,[6] a police detective could properly identify the defendant's signature because he had seen the defendant sign an arraignment form.

While expert witnesses identified handwriting based on a comparison with an individual's other writings in Dowdy v. State ,[7 ] nonexpert witnesses made such comparisons in Copeland v. State .[
8]
In Emory Healthcare, Inc. v. Pardue, [9] the daughter of a patient was permitted to tender medical bills regarding her mother's care.

In Rogers v. State ,[10] a statement by a department of corrections employee, at a trial to determine whether the defendant, who had been sentenced to death, was mentally retarded, that handwriting in the body of letters purportedly written by the defendant “appears to be that of [the defendant]” did not render employee's testimony too tentative to support a finding that letters were authentic. Likewise, a trustee's statement and gestures indicating a letter was from the defendant were not harmful error where the state had also presented other evidence that corroborated the defendant had penned the letter. Once the state presents such evidence, then it is up to the jury to determine the ultimate question of authenticity.[
11]

Authentication of telephone conversations is considered along with writings and is now easier under O.C.G.A. § 24-9-901(b)(6), which allows evidence that a call was made to the number assigned at the time by a telephone service provider to a particular person or business if circumstances, including self-identification, show the person answering to be the one called or that the call was made to a place of business and the conversation related to business reasonably transacted over the telephone.

An audiotape of a 911 call[12] or other tape-recorded conversations[13] can be authenticated by the testimony of one who was a party to the conversation recorded on the tape. Authentication of a document does not necessarily qualify it as an exception to the hearsay rule.

Trial court erred in striking documents attached as exhibits to an affidavit whose appearance, contents, substance, internal patterns, or other distinctive characteristics, taken in conjunction with circumstances, provided factors the trial court should have considered on the question of authentication. The documents bore logos, letterheads, telephone and facsimile numbers, e-mail addresses, and legal disclaimers; the proponents testified that the e-mails attached were retrieved from their servers; and some of the checks were tendered by the opposing party. Case was remanded for trial court to reconsider admissibility of the exhibits.[
14]

A writing may be authenticated by circumstantial evidence.[
15] In Burgess v. State, [16] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that a screenshot of defendant's MySpace page was properly admitted at trial based on circumstantial evidence. At defendant's trial for felony murder, witnesses testified that the accused was known by the nickname “Oops” and was a member of a gang, Murk Mob. The investigator testified that he confirmed defendant's nickname with his sister, accessed the defendant's publicly available MySpace profile page, and printed the screen-shot while confirming that it matched what he saw on the computer screen. Additionally, he compared the screen-shot photo to known photographs of the defendant, and confirmed defendant's age and place of origin with defendant's family. The court also allowed evidence of defendant's posts on Facebook which incriminated him where defendant's girlfriend testified that the picture on the page was the defendant, that the defendant went by the nickname on the page, that the defendant was from Indiana as listed on the page, and that the defendant had admitted to her that that was his Facebook page.[
17] Likewise, texts from a phone could be authenticated as having come from a particular defendant, even where the phone was registered to someone else, where the evidence showed that the defendant had unfettered access to the phone, and the defendant referred to himself in the first person in the printed out messages.[
18] At trial, defendant's letter, tendered to the state and purporting to be from a co-defendant, was admissible as evidence where the assistant district attorney who received the letter was available to testify, the letter contained intimate facts of the case as only someone involved would know, and the letter exonerated defendant in the matter.[
19]

Moreover, a document may be authenticated where it is produced by a party during discovery. In Blake v. KES, Inc., [20] the trial court improperly excluded exhibits when considering a party's motion for summary judgment because the documents were not self-authenticating. The Court of Appeals held that the exhibits the trial court excluded were created, prepared and completed by the opposing party and produced during discovery and therefore should have been considered by the trial court.[
21] Evidenced produced to support a motion for summary judgment must be authenticated to be admissible.[
22]

A videotape is authenticated by showing it is a fair representation of the object, scene, or person depicted.[
23] With respect to authenticating a video recording of a defendant's custodial statement, the state must show it is a fair representation of the statement, and may authenticate the recording by any witness familiar with the subject depicted.[
24]

There are no special rules for authenticating electronic documents or communications.[
25] Documents from electronic sources such as the printouts from a website like Facebook are subject to the same rules of authentication as other more traditional documentary evidence.[
26] Thus, authentication of text messages found on a defendant's phone by the detective in charge of the case was sufficient because the court could infer, circumstantially, that the messages belonged to the defendant since it was her phone, the detective had training to extract the messages, the phones had been safely stored, and the messages had not been altered since the phone was seized.[
27 ] Likewise, screen shots accurately depicting what the detective in the case viewed and printed out of the defendant's phone were sufficiently authenticated by the detective as being information in the defendant's phone. Argument as to whether these images could have been viewed by someone else on his phone without his authorization go to the weight, not the authenticity, of the evidence.[
28]
Blacks Law Dictionary (9th ed.).
Consolidated Freightways Corp. of Delaware v. Synchroflo, Inc., 164 Ga. App. 275, 294 S.E.2d 643 (1982).
Federal National Mortgage Association BR-027 v. Harris, 343 Ga. App. 295, 807 S.E.2d 75 (2017).
Allen v. State, 347 Ga. App. 731, 820 S.E.2d 747 (2018).
Williams v. State, 259 Ga. App. 742, 578 S.E.2d 128 (2003).
Dowdy v. State, 159 Ga. App. 805, 285 S.E.2d 764 (1981) .
Copeland v. State, 66 Ga. App. 142, 17 S.E.2d 288 (1941).
Emory Healthcare, Inc. v. Pardue, 328 Ga. App. 664, 760 S.E.2d 674 (2014).
Rogers v. State, 282 Ga. 659, 653 S.E.2d 31 (2007).
Brown v. State, 332 Ga. App. 635, 774 S.E.2d 708 (2015).
Harris v. State, 296 Ga. App. 465, 675 S.E.2d 236 (2009).
Saunders v. Padovani, 258 Ga. 866, 375 S.E.2d 853 (1989) .
RCO Legal, P.S., Inc. v. Johnson, 347 Ga. App. 661, 820 S.E.2d 491 (2018).

In Smith v. State, 154 Ga. App. 102, 267 S.E.2d 629 (1980), the letters had not been properly authenticated. However, this case was vacated and remanded in State v. Smith, 246 Ga. 129, 269 S.E.2d 21 (1980), where it was held that the writing had been sufficiently authenticated by circumstantial evidence.
Burgess v. State, 292 Ga. 821, 742 S.E.2d 464 (2013). See also Smoot v. State, 316 Ga. App. 102, 729 S.E.2d 416 (2012); Hammontree v. State, 283 Ga. App. 736, 642 S.E.2d 412 (2007).
Glispie v. State, 335 Ga. App. 177, 779 S.E.2d 767 (2015), opinion vacated in part on other grounds, 341 Ga. App. 817, 801 S.E.2d 910 (2017).
Amey v. State, 337 Ga. App. 480, 788 S.E.2d 80 (2016) .
Blake v. KES, Inc., 329 Ga. App. 742, 766 S.E.2d 138 (2014).

See also Koules v. SP5 Atlantic Retail Ventures, LLC, 330 Ga. App. 282, 767 S.E.2d 40 (2014), where the court reversed evidentiary findings by the trial court on consideration of a motion for summary judgment where documents produced by the plaintiff were introduced by the defendant but the trial court refused to consider them because the defendants did not produce a witness to authenticate the documents.

But see Thomason v. FIA Card Services, N.A., 330 Ga. App. 603, 768 S.E.2d 785 (2015), where the court held the documents attached to a summary judgment motion were not properly authenticated where the account referenced in the affidavit attached to the motion and the account referenced in the complaint had two different account numbers.
Hungry Wolf/Sugar & Spice, Inc. v. Langdeau, 338 Ga. App. 750, 791 S.E.2d 850 (2016).

State v. Smith, 299 Ga. 901, 792 S.E.2d 677 (2016) (trial court erred where it allowed the testimony of a detective who admitted he had not seen the video, was not present when the statement was made, and was not familiar with the duration of the statement).
Johnson v. State, 348 Ga. App. 667, 824 S.E.2d 561 (2019) .
Hawkins v. State, 304 Ga. 299, 818 S.E.2d 513 (2018).
Johnson v. State, 348 Ga. App. 667, 824 S.E.2d 561 (2019).
Holzheuser v. State, 828 S.E.2d 664 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
